The Foreign Secretary was much more full-blooded today. If he can make that sort of speech, why cannot he write a Motion saying what he feels, putting it down in black and white? From these benches we wish to demonstrate firm general support of the United States in Vietnam.
The hon. Gentleman the Member for Fife, West (Mr. William Hamilton), in his new rôle—a very agreeable rôle, and one which would almost qualify him for a seat in another place—[Laughter.]such statesmanship did he show today in putting most polite questions to the Opposition and making the most rough
and vigorous charges against his own colleagues below the Gangway. He asked me to say what the Opposition would do, where they would stop in supporting the Americans, and I shall answer his question. But the Foreign Secretary quite rightly said, of course, that r o British Government, no one in the British House of Commons, can say "We will support everything the Americans do right or wrong." What we are saying is that in this question of the American bombing of military targets in Vietnam the American Government were right and the judgment of the British Prime Minister was wrong—[HON. MEMBERS: "Answer."] This we have stated—
The right hon. Gentleman refuses to answer my question, which was: would the Opposition approve of the sending of British troops and/or the use of the nuclear weapon?

These questions Lave not arisen—[HON. MEMBERS: "Answer."]—if they do we judge these matters on their merits—[HON. MEMBERS: "Answer."]—and we support—[Interruption.] I will have to cut in to the Prime Minister's time at this rate. We support the American policy as it has been revealed, and the actions the Americans have taken—[HON. MEMBERS: "Answer."]
We do not know what further action they will take—[HON. MEMBERS: "Answer."]—but we judge the alliance quite differently from most hon. and right lion. Members opposite. We do not say, as the hon. Member did, that to dissociate ourselves from the American alliance is a useful and a good weapon to have in our hands. That is not the spirit in which we approach the American alliance, but we judge every case on its merits and because the merits of supporting the Americans in this case are overwhelming, we shall go into the Lobby in support of our Amendment.

The House will feel that what was for the right hon. Member for Kinross and West Perthshire (Sir Alec Douglas-Home) a highly effective speech was completely ruined in the last three minutes when he failed to reply to the
question which my hon. Friend the Member for Fife, West (Mr. William Hamilton) had addressed to him.
I should like to thank the right hon. Member for the good wishes he expressed to me and for his advice and counsel about dealings with the Kremlin. I am sure it was not his intention that his advice should sound so patronising.— [HON. MEMBERS: "Shame."]—I recognise, of course, that he has had substantial dealings with the Kremlin. He will recognise that I was dealing with them also successfully seven years before he became a junior Minister.
When the right hon. Gentleman asked me—[Interruption.]—when the right hon. Gentleman asked me about infiltration in Laos and referred to the report of the Control Commission, as did the Leader of the Opposition, certainly I had that report in mind and certainly its conclusions were well known to us. Indeed, as I have said more than once in this House, it was the fact of infiltration down the Ho Chi-Minh trail—trail it was then, now it is a paved highway—from North Vietnam which led us to support early last year the change in American policy in relation to the bombing of North Vietnam. Although many hon. Members in many parts of the House have referred to breaches of the 1954 Agreement by all parties, it is a fact, of course, that the 1962 Agreement on Laos with which the right hon. Gentleman was so much concerned was in fact breached from the moment Laos was used as a route of entry into Vietnam.
Indeed, I think it is very sad for many of us on both sides of the House that the right hon. Gentleman who negotiated for this neutralist establishment in Laos, for those of us who supported him and pressed him in that work to feel that many of the high hopes we had in Laos two or three years ago have been to some extent frustrated by the regular use of Laos as a supply route into Vietnam.
When he referred to what he thought was a one-sided approach by some hon. Members calling only for an end to the bombing and not for the end of infiltration, the right hon. Gentleman will be aware that it has been the policy of the Government throughout—it was indeed a central feature of the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' communiqué
on Vietnam last year—that we called for an end of the bombing and of the infiltration as a means of getting an end to hostilities before we could have peace negotiations for a settlement in Vietnam.
Every debate on Vietnam is characterised by great passion, great feeling and great emotion, and understandably so. Everybody in this House, whatever our different points of view, shares the anxieties and the feelings that have been expressed in very graphic terms from different parts of the House and by hon. Members of different points of view about this cruel war in Vietnam. Whatever may divide us—we are divided about the policy that ought to be followed by various of the parties to this dispute, and indeed, by Her Majesty's Government themselves—we are united, every one of us, in our passionate desire—[Interruption.] Perhaps I might appeal to the right hon. Gentleman to rise above his frivolity and take this Vietnam subject with the seriousness which it demands. I was saying that we are united, every one of us—[Laughter.] If hon. Members, who asked for this debate, regard the tragedies of Vietnam as a laughing matter, I can only express my profoundest regret.
I was saying that we are united, every one of us, even those who are laughing and tittering about this Vietnam tragedy—I hope we are united—in our passionate desire to see this war ended at the earliest possible moment. The reasons why we are united about it have been set out by many of us today and in other debates. First, every day that this war continues means the death of more innocent Vietnamese, North and South. To men, women and children it means maiming and mutilation; it means children rendered fatherless, it means families rendered homeless, in a country to which peace has been a stranger now for almost a generation.
Hon. Members have referred to barbarism. Modern war is barbarous and sufferings are not confined to one side. Some of my hon. Friends have referred to the victims of bombing in North Vietnam. All of us have been aware, equally, of those who have suffered as a result of murderous attacks on peaceful villages in the South, because these are part, as
we all recognise, of civil war. And a civil war, as in part this is, yields to no other kind of war in atrocities and barbarism.
This will continue as long as the war lasts. This is why it is the duty of every one of us to bring our counsel, aid and resolve, because, without all these, expressions of sympathy are simply empty phrases, not in condemnation, but to laying conditions which could bring this fight to an end at the earliest possible moment. This is one factor which unites us in our determination to end the war.
Equally, we are concerned about the international dangers of this war, the dangers of it spreading into a conflagration covering a far wider part of Asia. Here we cannot exclude the parallel danger of aggression and infiltration into other parts of Asia which, if it is not met with resistance in Vietnam, might spread into other countries which are still at peace. We have to look into these factors when we consider what our policy should be.
There are those who, seeing no possible end to this war, are fearful, not only of its spreading in geographical terms to other parts of Asia, but of an escalation to the frontiers of a nuclear war, perhaps to a thermo-nuclear holocaust. These are the stakes we are debating today.
There is a third reason. All our hopes and dreams of reducing East-West tension in Europe, and more widely than Europe, hopes which all of us feel are matched by real possibilities at this time, remain unfulfilled because this Vietnamese war spreads a cloud of poison over East-West relations. I am convinced, as right hon. Members opposite have said at various times—indeed, hon. Members in all parts of the House have said this—that the Soviet Union is ready, as we are, for practical moves towards reducing East-West tension, that an advance in the field of disarmament and arms control could be within our grasp. Anyone who has talked, as so many of us in all parts of the House have, with Soviet statesmen and others in these past years, and especially over the past 18 months, will know that the Vietnamese conflict lays an icy hand on all our hopes.
So far we are all agreed about the three urgent reasons why this war should be brought to an end. I come to where
we disagree. May I say that in our disagreement I accept the deep sincerity of those who are critical of the Government's basic policy as fully as I ask them to believe in mine and that of my right hon. Friends. Where we disagree is in the means of a solution and in the difficulties of a solution and the cause of those difficulties. Indeed, perhaps there is not all that disagreement about the means of a solution. I think all of us recognise now that the problems of Vietnam no longer lend themselves, if they ever did lend themselves, to a purely military solution. I have not heard the argument put forward recently that this problem can be solved with a military solution. There can be no imposed solution by either side. Only a political settlement—one that is also acceptable to the people of Vietnam themselves—can end this war.
Some of us have talked at various times about this but there are those outside this House who carry banners calling for peace in Vietnam. Last weekend there was a march down Whitehall. It came into Downing Street. There were the usual banners with slogans, one of them "Peace in Vietnam". But there was another which said "Victory for the Vietcong". These are incompatible ends. One can talk about victory for someone but not about peace in Vietnam at the same time.
This is why the House will have noted the cynical attitude of the Chinese Prime Minister when he was in Rumania last week. The House will have seen reports in the British Press from Eastern European sources that he told the Rumanian leader that even the destruction of most of Vietnam would be justified by the result, the eventual emergence of a superior Communist society. No one in this House shares the view that this war is to go on to the bitter end to secure victory for one or the other political ideology. It is the view of all of us that we want to see talks so that peace can be negotiated on lines acceptable to the people of Vietnam themselves. That is the view of the United States Government, as it is our view and the view of everyone in this House.
Most of us believe that the right solution would lie in the reactivation of the Geneva Conference so that all parties concerned could negotiate a peaceful
settlement. That has been said from both Front Benches for almost as long as we have been debating Vietnam. All of us would feel that such a conference is possible without a prior cease-fire—that it would be possible to negotiate in Geneva even while the fighting went on. However that may be, I think that we would feel that the hopes of a compromise—the give and take needed to get an acceptable solution—would be less easily heard against the background of gunfire or bombing or stealthy infiltration and murder.
The right hon. Gentleman the Leader of the Opposition said that we should be giving thought now to two main subjects—first, how to get a peace conference opened—a matter which has exercised all of us for a long time—and, secondly, the outcome that we want to see emerge from the negotiations. That is not exactly a new point, but perhaps it has not been stressed so much.
I remind the right hon. Gentleman that more than a year ago the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference gave a great deal of thought to these matters and that they issued a statement—all 20 of them, including the Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand, to whom the right hon. Gentleman referred. Last October the Labour Party conference unanimously endorsed a statement based on the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' proposals both on the means of getting peace talks started and on the kind of outcome we hoped they would lead to. The Government Motion is completely consistent with both statements. Apart from the necessary House of Commons language, it represents word for word the Labour Party manifesto, which derived from the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' communiqué.
In view of what has been said, I remind the House that the guide-lines for the proposed Commonwealth Peace Mission included the following statement, which, repeat, was agreed on by all Commonwealth Prime Ministers:
"(a) a suspension of all United States air attacks on North Vietnam;
(b) a North Vietnamese undertaking to prevent the movement of any military forces or assistance or material to South Vietnam;"
These two are bracketed together, as the right hon. Gentleman said.
(c) a total cease-fire on all sides to enable a conference to be convened to seek a peaceful solution; (d) the objectives of such a conference might be to:
(i) end the war in Vietnam;
(ii) secure the withdrawal of all foreign military presence from Vietnam and the neutralisation of the area;
(iii) establish, for a period, an international peace force, under the auspices of the Geneva Agreement, to safeguard peace in Vietnam;
(iv) establish principles for the eventual unification of the country through free and internationally supervised elections."
That was a clear statement.
Obviously, an ultimate solution must be a matter for negotiations and on the whole I would deprecate going into too much detail about what is to emerge. But I remind the House that the United States President has recently again called for unconditional negotiations—unconditional—and that he has laid down no conditions as to the outcome of these negotiations. The problem is, of course, that we have the five Phan Van Dong conditions from Hanoi—there were four and there is now a fifth which is more difficult than the others—saying that in the negotiations not merely must the Viet-cong be represented—which is a reasonable claim which many of us have pressed—but that only the Vietcong shall be represented as speaking for the people of South Vietnam.
The right hon. Gentleman the Leader of the Opposition this afternoon seemed to be criticising some of the parts of our Motion which looked to the future at the end of the fighting and the end of the negotiations. But if he has doubts about parts of that formula, I have to say that he is quarrelling not only with me, which is fairly familiar ground between us, but with virtually the whole Commonwealth in so far as it expressed itself in that communiqué of a year ago. Nevertheless, we all recognise his right to an independent judgment on this if he feels that the Commonwealth is wrong.
This afternoon my right hon. Friend once again gave the House a summary of all that we have done to try to bring the parties to the conference table. Of course it is true that all of these efforts have failed. But I beseech the right hon. Gentleman to dissociate himself from the
argument that an initiative which fails is one which ought never to have been undertaken. That is only too easy. There were and there still are a lot of jibes about the Commonwealth Peace Mission whenever it is mentioned in the House from some hon. Member opposite. But, as I have said, this was the view of 20 Commonwealth Prime Ministers and it was enthusiastically supported by, among others, the Prime Minister of Australia, a country to which the right hon. Gentleman frequently referred in his speech today. It was accepted and supported in a great part of the world including Washington.
The fact that Hanoi refused to accept it does not mean that it was wrong to try to get it established, particularly since, for reasons which I have more than once explained to the House, it was not possible to invoke the United Nations for a settlement to this question precisely because of the difficulties of using the Security Council, and the whole House knows of those difficulties. It was, therefore, essential to try to invoke the next best thing, namely, the Commonwealth, representing one-quarter of the world's population and one-fifth of the number of countries in the United Nations and representing every conceivable point of view, non-aligned and pro one side or the other, in the Vietnam dispute.
Few things caused right hon. Gentlemen opposite more innocent fun than the mission of my hon. Friend the Joint Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Pensions and National Insurance to Hanoi last year, but his task was to bring home to the authorities in Hanoi the views of the Commonwealth Mission and the Commonwealth communiqué and to assure them of the sincerity of the 20 Commonwealth statesmen who had joined in taking this initiative. I hope that a year' later, even though that Mission failed, right hon. Gentlemen opposite will no longer think that it was wrong to try, or that it would be wrong to try the next time.
I have told the House often enough, when we have heard from right hon. Gentlemen opposite that we wanted patient diplomatic discussions through Moscow, that the key to this problem lies in Hanoi. That is why we have tried every possible means, and some of
them very unorthodox, as I concede, for getting the message through to Hanoi. When I was in Moscow in February, my noble Friend the Minister of State at the Foreign Office, Lord Chalfont, met the chargé d'affaires of the North 'Vietnamese Republic and argued with him for four hours. It failed, but we were right to try and we are right to go on trying.
Today we have the proposal of the Prime Minister of India which, as my right hon. Friend said, we welcome and which, because it is an appeal to the Co-Chairmen, we shall of course study with the utmost urgency. It is very much on lines which we welcome. One point which perhaps I should make right away is that it would seem from the formulation that the Prime Minister of India is talking as though it is necessary to get o cease-fire first. We all believe that this is desirable. On the other hand 1 would not feel, if there is no alternative, that we ought to insist on a ceasefire as a condition for negotiation. As I have said, this was the decision of the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference. It wanted a cease-fire but did not insist upon it. Let us not get into the position of saying that because 20 initiatives have failed, it is wrong to try a twenty-first.
Having dealt with the basic problems, because these have been the subject of many speeches by my hon. Friends, I now turn to deal with the question of last week's statement of dissociation from the bombing of the oil installations.
rose—

I have a lot of ground to cover and a lot to answer. I am trying to understand here the position of the right hon. Gentleman. I must say that he spoke this afternoon with much greater moderation than at the weekend, when he was speaking in the country. His argument, as I understood it this afternoon, was that we support the United States in resistance to aggression for the reasons stated by my right hon. Friend and endorsed by the right hon. Gentleman, and that we were therefore wrong to dissociate ourselves from any action considered militarily necessary or of measurable military advantage which helped American troops there having regard also to the fact that
there are Australian and New Zealand ground forces there, too. At the weekend the right hon. Gentleman put it rather more extravagantly. He said that this Government, in dissociating themselves, were ratting on our American allies. That was the phrase he used and I am trying to analyse his argument. Is he saying that we must commit ourselves, automatically to support any action for which there is a strong—
rose—

We listened very quietly to the right hon. Gentleman this afternoon. I want to go right through the logic of his argument. Is he saying that we must commit ourselves automatically to support any action for which there is a strong case, without any regard to wider considerations? He was asked this afternoon whether he would interpret this doctrine as meaning that he would support nuclear action. His answer was that this was hypothetical. Of course the whole question of the bombing of the oil installations was hypothetical until a week or two ago.
It is right to say that we had clearly stated our attitude in advance—not a day in advance, not a week in advance, but more than six months ago, and stated where it ought to be stated, to President Johnson himself. He understood the position absolutely clearly. We have stated this position publicly in this House last December and subsequently, and I hope that right hon. Gentlemen will feel that we were right to say this six months ago, when we saw this danger, rather than say that it was a hypothetical question and that we would wait until the bombing.
The right hon. Gentleman went so far as to say that he would be opposed to bombing civilian centres. I understood him to say this and this presumably would not be ratting on our allies. This is a matter of principle, and he thinks this is right. The oil installations were, as has been said, two miles from the city centre. Every effort was made, superhuman efforts were made, within the policy decision to carry out the bombing, to keep civilian casualties to an absolute minimum, as would be expected. But if it is wrong to bomb centres of a city, and wrong for us to dissociate ourselves from
the bombing two miles from the centre, where do we have to draw the line?
I am not saying that the right hon. Gentleman's argument is unrealistic or illogical. I am saying that it must be a matter of judgment, and that on his argument one has to draw an arbitrary line somewhere. This must be a matter of degree and judgment, up which we can honestly disagree in this House, or between ourselves and our American allies or the Australians and New Zealanders, about the difference between two miles from the city centre and one mile away. Whether it is right to dissociate can only be a question of honest judgment and it does not deserve the use of the extravagant language used by the right hon. Gentleman at the weekend. We believe in our obligations as Co-Chairmen. These are not laid down from Mount Sinai in tablets of stone. They must be matters of judgment, but our interpretation is different from the Russians, and is more austere. We do not go so far as the North Vietnamese, who say that they will not talk to anyone who supports the United States. But we believe that there are responsibilities upon us because we are Co-Chairmen. President Johnson stated this clearly in Washington a few months ago, and said that he recognised this obligation.
I should like to know whether the right hon. Gentleman accepts that the Co-Chairmanship carries with it separate obligations—for example, obligations different from the position of the Australian and New Zealand Governments. I do not know whether he feels that we are on the same footing or whether the Co-Chairmanship makes a difference. Let me give an example: they send troops, we do not because we are Co-Chairman. Does he agree that we are right? He owes it to the House to say whether he believes—[Interruption.]—I have said that as Co-Chairman we cannot consider sending troops.
rose—

I am sorry; I want to put a question to the right hon. Gentleman. I have said that as co-Chairman we are not sending troops. The right hon. Member for Wolverhampton,—[Interruption.] As Co-Chairman we could not, and we have not consid-
ered sending troops for that reason; and for a second reason, which I agree is now ending, namely, the confrontation in Malaysia. But as Co-Chairman we are not sending troops. I want to know whether the right hon. Gentleman agrees with that, whether he feels that we should send troops, or whether he still agrees that as Co-Chairman we should not send troops, because if he is saying that he is drawing the line again at a point where we are in a different position from the Americans; and I do not think that he would say that we were ratting if we did not send troops. That is ate point which I wanted to ask him about.
I turn to our Motion, which represents the policy of Her Majesty's Government. It is in full accord with the policies we have outlined in successive debates. The right hon. Gentleman referred to the need for deep thought to be given, not only to the means of getting the parties round the conference table, but to the ultimate solution which may emerge from it. As I have said, we have a duty to do this. Certainly, if we can compare the conditions of Phan Van Dong and, as I would call it, unconditional insistence by the United States on negotiations—that is our position, too—there is obviously a very great gap to bridge between that and the Phan Van Dong conditions. But the President of the United States said, "Let us go without conditions and they can bring up the Phan Van Dong conditions if they want to". But when we say in the Motion that this area should be neutral without foreign troops or bases, this is in accordance with what United States leaders have said a number of times.
Unlike the right hon. Gentleman's Amendment, what we say in this statement is what we said in the election. This statement, apart from the last 20 words or so, is taken word for word from the manifesto which we put before the country and upon which all my hon. Friends were elected to the House. [HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."] Yes. The final words do not represent any change of policy on the part of Her Majesty's Government because, as I have explained, they are the expression after the event, namely, the bombing, of what we always said was our position long before the event. It was stated in the House on
21st December. Can the right hon. Gentleman say the same about his Amendment?
I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition remembers these words on 26th March, five days before polling day in the General Election, when admittedly right hon. and hon. Members opposite were getting desperate: Under the Labour Government in the last 18 months, Britain has behaved perfectly clearly and perfectly recognisably as an American satellite…. While the Americans have ground deeper and deeper into the tragic morass of Vietnam, Britain's voice has been that of the obedient commentator. Each successive American act received prompt British endorsement. The Soviet Union could hardly have expected more favourable comment from its satrapes in Eastern Europe. Those words were used by the right hon. Gentleman's defence spokesman five day's before polling day and they were never repudiated by the right hon. Gentleman. certainly not before the election was over. It was only after the election that he ordered his right hon. Friend to hold his tongue.
But that is not all. [Interruption.] This is not a red herring. The right hon. Gentleman also said on 26th March after referring to Vietnam: Over and over again it has been left to the Tory Party and above all to Mr. Hoath himself, to voice the legitimate claim of this country to a rational independence and distinctiveness of outlook and of policy. [Interruption.] I will not weary the House with the speeches of the right hon. Gentleman the Leader of the Opposition himself, unless he presses me. With subtlety and cool calculation he managed during the election to convey that it was the Labour Party which was too close to the Americans, and he played cleverly on what he conceived to be the latent anti-American feeling in the country to which members of the Tory Party always appeal in their moments of desperation. They did it at the time of Suez, they did it over Katanga, and they
did it in the election last March. They give the impression at these times, somehow, that the Conservative Party—[Interruption.]
Mr. Goodhew rose—
Order. The right hon. Gentleman has obviously not given way.

I want the hon. Member for St. Albans (Mr. Goodhew) to realise as well as the right hon. Gentleman what we were elected on. I want right hon. and hon. Members opposite, before they go into the Division Lobby, to recognise the extent to which they are dissociating themselves from what they said at the election, whereas we are voting for the precise policy that we put before the electorate, because those were the things that right hon. and hon. Members opposite were saying when they were seeking votes.
Now they are speaking in a different tone, and the difference is that the Motion on which we shall be voting represents, thought by thought and word for word, what we said and what we fought on when we were seeking from the country the mandate which we are now carrying out. That mandate was to do everything in our power to seek to bring the fighting in Vietnam to an end. That is what we are doing. We shall expect the usual jibes on any initiative which we take that may fail. [HON. MEMBERS: "They all fail."] Twenty may fail, and another 20 may fail, but we shall still go on trying. The trouble with hon. Gentlemen opposite and especially the right hon. Gentleman is that he never wins anything because he is never prepared to lose first.
Question put, That the words proposed to be left out stand part of the Question:—
The House divided: Ayes 331, Noes 230.

speech.p: Resolved,

That this House, deeply anxious to see an end to the cruel war in Vietnam and recalling Her Majesty's Government's repeated urgings that all parties concerned in the dispute should enter into negotiations to stop the fighting and achieve a settlement which would enable the peoples of North and South Vietnam to determine their own future and which would ensure
that the whole country became neutral without foreign troops or bases, approves Her Majesty's Government's determination to pursue their efforts to promote the unconditional negotiations already accepted by the United States but so far rejected by North Vietnam; and endorses Her Majesty's Government's announcement on 29th June of its decision to dissociate itself from the bombing of oil installations in the Hanoi and Haiphong areas.

I wish, first, to thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his courtesy in coming to the House this evening at comparatively short notice to hear what I have to say, the more so because what I have to say
to him will be of a very censorious kind. What I have to do this evening is to undertake the unpleasant task of saying that the Parliamentary Secretary was ostensibly—I repeat "ostensibly"—guilty of a major discourtesy yesterday to a large number of my constituents and members of the adjoining constituency by failing to keep an appointment which I understand had been fixed at his suggestion some days or weeks previously, and for which it is obvious that extensive preparation had been made.
My constituency includes about one-third of the area which has been designated for the Dawley New Town, the other two-thirds being in the adjoining constituency of The Wrekin. The planning of the new town has gone through a number of difficult stages. It is in the hands of a highly respected and competent development authority which had taken responsibility for all the arrangements for the expected visit of the Parliamentary Secretary. I understand that all these preparations having been made—indeed I was invited some 10 days previously, an invitation which unfortunately I had to refuse on account of duties here—the event was cancelled at what appears to have been something less than 24 hours' notice. I was informed today by one of the local councillors who had been asked to attend that it was not until Wednesday morning that the letter arrived at the breakfast table from the Clerk to the Council to say that unfortunately the whole event was cancelled.
This may seem a small matter for those who do not know the district. The reason for having a new town in the Dawley area has been partly the poor and very under-developed state of the whole area, and that is a state of affairs which has provided exceptional difficulties for the development authority which has undertaken this task. Even to find offices it has had to go five miles away to a country house, and in order to carry out the essential services in the centre of the area it has had to build a temporary building. It has had to use an old-fashioned building called a town hall.
With those rather rudimentary bits of equipment it takes immense trouble on these occasions to make visits as interesting and as agreeable as is possible. The Parliamentary Secretary knows that the Minister paid two visits to this area
last year. I was privileged to be present on one occasion and I was able to see the efforts which are made. In particular, the arrangements for yesterday included a lunch, to which the Parliamentary Secretary had been invited. The Development Corporation has an excellent caterer who, in conditions which cannot be at all easy, manages to put on a quite excellent lunch. I can assure the Parliamentary Secretary that, quite apart from any other disappointment which he may have had, he missed what I am sure would have been an excellent entertainment.
The serious part of this matter is the impression which is bound to have been created locally. This visit had been widely advertised and it is fair to say that it was very necessary. In the early stages of the development of a new town a development authority obviously has one important link, and that is with the Ministry of Housing by which it is financed and to some extent guided. When a visit from a Minister is advertised, it is a local event. People feel that some interest is being taken in their problems. When it is cancelled at 24 hours' notice, clearly the effects cannot be very good.
There are a number of problems which doubtless the Minister was going down to the area to see for himself. Before I say a word about those, I must ask the question: what was the reason that justified this sudden cancellation? The Ministry of Housing is not one of the Ministries subject to sudden emergencies which require all the Ministers to be in their London headquarters or, indeed, in some other part of the country. Unquestionably, only one conclusion locally can have been drawn from this sudden cancellation, and that was that the Parliamentary Secretary was kept in London, not for any matter connected with his Ministry but with a matter connected with his party. Unquestionably, the conclusion must have been drawn that he had been ordered to remain in London in order to attend the meeting which it is known was being held that morning by the Parliamentary Labour Party.
I do not say that that conclusion is correct, but perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary will tell the House. If it was so, I suggest that it raises a number of
questions. Has the Labour Party really got to the point that if a matter of policy has to be discussed all the Ministers have to be present at the party meeting? Secondly, there is the more serious question that if Ministers have contracted, as obviously Ministers have to do, appointments outside London, on important missions such as visiting what is to be, after all, the largest new town in the country, is it right that appointments should be suddenly cancelled, not for any reason of national emergency, not for any reason of crisis in the Ministry itself, but for a reason affecting the Government political party? If this is to be the rule in this country, I am bound to say that Government in this country has fallen to a very low point indeed. I hope that we may have something from the Minister on that, which is, I think, the most important aspect of what I have to say.
In view of what has happened, it is fair that I should ask the Parliamentary Secretary what he feels were the important objects of his visit. I understand from the local Press that he wished to have an opportunity to view the initiation of what I think has been called the "continuity plan". The continuity plan in Dawley is a development which has had to take place as a result of the decision recently made by the Labour Government, when it was proposed that the designated area should be enlarged by the addition of a much greater area to the north, including such places as Oakengates and Wellington.
That had rather serious repercussions on the plans of the development authority, because it meant that in the northern part of the designated area—that part which is not in my constituency—there really had to be a standstill. The Authority had to switch all its activities to the southern part of the area, which is in my constituency—that is why this matter particularly concerns me. The Authority had to revise all its original arrangements. It had to make what has appeared to be a major change of plan, and one which it is very necessary that the Minister should view on the spot—the question of the allocation of a particular area for a possible university.
Dawley new town is to be a very large place when it is completed. If we have
this additional area which the Government now propose, it may be an area containing 150,000 people, and clearly might justify a university. There is in the southern part of the designated area a site which suggests itself as being ideally suitable to be reserved for a university site. It is on a plateau overlooking what must originally have been a very fine scene of the Severn Gorge, and which now might be restored to its original beauty. In the continuity plan, all that has had to be scrapped and the area has had to be allocated for housing. I am far from certain that that is a wise decision. It is not in any case one that would, I should think, need to be implemented or finalised immediately. Surely it is a decision which, before it goes beyond recall, would justify a visit from the Minister. Indeed, that was specifically mentioned as a possible objective of the hon. Gentleman's visit.
Other matters which must be in the forefront of the Minister's mind in any such scheme would include the interests of those living in the area, particularly the settlements of Madeley, one of the centres in my constituency, where the proposal is to compulsorily purchase large numbers of houses and, in effect, redesign what is now the urban centre.
I have had a number of letters from present occupiers complaining of the prospects threatening them. In fairness to the Development Corporation, however, I must say that it has taken, in my view, great pains to study the interests of he present residents. It is remarkable not that I have had letters but that I have had so few. But this is a matter which would surely be in the forefront of the mind of a Minister visiting the area.
What is more important to the future is the whole question of industrial development. To what extent is this the responsibility of the Ministry of Housing and Local Government and to what extent is it that of the Board of Trade? To what extent is it a joint responsibility? This subject has been brought up by the case of the important firm of Archdale which was very anxious to move into this area. I am not acquainted with all the details of the negotiations and the dealings with the various Ministries which took place, but he upshot was that the firm did not come.
This has created considerable concern among a number of people in the area, notably some of the councillors, who rightly think that, if the new town is to get off the ground, the basis of it must be live and powerful industries. The firm concerned seemed to many people an ideal industry to be brought in to the new town at an early stage and it is disturbing that a firm of this kind should have been prevented from moving in, apparently for the doctrinaire reason that it did not come from the right area.
I should be grateful if the hon. Gentleman could say something precise about this because it carries serious implications for the future, particularly the early future, of Dawley if it must be the rule that every industry which wishes to go there must come from a defined area. What is important, too, is not only the area from which it comes but also what is the technical designation of the Dawley area itself. Is it or is it not a development area? The main question is, I repeat, to what extent it is the responsibility of the hon. Gentleman's Ministry and to what extent it is the responsibility of the Board of Trade.
Two other matters are outstanding and are of importance. The first is the report, sent to me from the Ministry in February, of a housing study undertaken under its aegis. It was to be published "in due course". I do not expect the hon. Member to be able to answer now but apparently the report had special reference to new towns. I would be grateful if he could say something about this, however.
Secondly, and more important, is the report of the consultant advising on the northern area. The hon. Member for The Wrekin (Mr. Fowler) asked a Question about this a few days ago and the Written Answer to him appeared to be that the report is being slightly delayed for various reasons. Delay has been a bugbear of the new town from its inception. I should be grateful to be given some idea of when it is hoped the report will appear.
My primary objective is on behalf of my constituents and the Development Corporation. Although I have complained, however, I have not been asked to do so. I am saying what I would be saying if I were one of those responsible for arranging the hon. Gentleman's visit.
I also want to say that I cannot believe, unless the Parliamentary Secretary tells us so, that he was in any way personally responsible for what has happened. The right course to adopt over this unfortunate incident is for the Prime Minister or the Minister of Housing and Local Government to appear at the Dispatch Box at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning and publicly apologise to my constituents and all those inconvenienced.

I am a little surprised that this matter should have been raised tonight by the hon. Member for Ludlow (Mr. More), not least because, as he has told us, he had not intended to be present yesterday on the occasion of this important visit to his constituency, and to mine, of one of the Ministers concerned with the development of the new town. I had intended to be present. The local paper tonight records that the Minister was not there to meet the list of distinguished guests, including myself, but not including the hon. Member.
Before I was informed that the visit was cancelled, I found that I would have been unable to go. This was not because there was a Parliamentary Labour Party meeting—I set the interests of my constituents above that. It was because the Front Bench opposite, led by the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Enfield, West (Mr. Iain Macleod), had decided to censure, not the conduct of the Government or the conduct of any Minister, but the conduct of the Chairman of Ways and Means, and to censure him in a singularly half-hearted, weak-willed manner.
I was kept here, and I have little doubt that my hon. Friend was kept here too. because the right hon. Gentleman decided that yesterday was a suitable occasion for leading the troops on the benches opposite, not only towards the sound of gunfire, but into the gun barrels of my hon. and right hon. Friends. That is why I am surprised that this complaint should come from the benches opposite. I have been on the telephone to various members of the Dawley Urban District Council and have found that there was every understanding why the visit was cancelled. The hon. Gentleman the
Member for Ludlow rightly draws attention to the fact that the development of the area has been affected by delay in deciding whether to extend the area of the new town northwards. I too have raised this matter in this Session.
The point I wish to make is that this delay would never have occurred if the correct decision about the designation of the new town area had been taken in the first place, before my right hon. and hon. Friends formed the Government. Delay is essentially the result of a failure of political conviction in the last Conservative administration.

speech.speakername: The Joint Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Housing and Local Government (Mr. Robert Mellish)
speech.p:
I am sorry that the hon. Gentleman the Member for Ludlow (Mr. More) saw fit, when he initiated this debate, to accuse me of what he called major discourtesy by failing to attend Dawley yesterday and imputed, by those words, that I had taken a deliberate action which had caused such grave offence to his constituents. He knows me well enough by now. I have been a Member of this House for 20 years and I might be almost the last person to be involved in an incident of that kind, unless there was an absolutely justifiable reason for it.
As my hon. Friend the Member for The Wrekin (Mr. Fowler) has said, the reason is that I was informed—after having made all the arrangements with the usual channels in view of what the business of the House for the coming week was going to be—that Her Majesty's Opposition had put down a major Motion of censure against the Chairman of Ways and Means and that there would be a Three-Line Whip. I was told that a vote was expected from 5 o'clock onwards. Obviously I could not get to Dawley and do the job which I had to go down to do, to see these very important people, doing a very important job, and be back in this House by 5 o'clock. I did not know of these arrangements until 24 hours before my intended visit.
Therefore, I had no alternative, as my hon. Friend the Member for The Wrekin rightly mentioned, but to send telegrams, and make phone calls, including a personal phone call to the chairman of the
Development Corporation at his hotel, expressing my profound regret. After that to be told by a member of the Opposition that initiated what I call the "glorious disaster" of yesterday—when, in fact, there was not a vote—that I am the one responsible for this major discourtesy, is just about more than even I can take.
Let us get this on record for those who read matters of this kind, and I hope that the local Press in Dawley will at least print this part of my speech. I am terribly sorry that I was not able to get there, because I was looking forward to meeting them and the local authorities there to hear about their problems, and not least to talk with those many people who are inevitably engaged in such a major project as building a new town.
I want straight away to deal with some of the points raised by the hon. Member for Ludlow and the overall picture of Dawley and nearby towns following the West Midlands Study, which was published in July, 1965. At that time the Dawley new town was to be planned for a population of some 80,000 to 90,000 people. The West Midlands Study recommended that consideration be given to taking on a further 50,000 overspill from Birmingham and the Black Country in the neighbouring towns of Wellington and Oakengates. It seemed sensible to my right hon. Friend that the planning studies of Wellington and Oakengates could not ignore the plans already in course of preparation for Dawley.
He decided, therefore, to appoint consultants to prepare reports in two stages. First, the consultants were asked to recommend for my right hon. Friend consideration of an appropriate area founded on Wellington-Oakengates for further development, in conjunction with development of the existing Dawley new town, and they were asked to report on it during this month.
Secondly, the consultants were asked to submit proposals by November, 1967, for an overall plan for development of the Dawley and Wellington-Oakengates areas. By that time the consultants already engaged by the Dawley Development Corporation had gone quite a long way in preparing a master plan for the new town. It therefore seemed sensible to appoint the same consultants for the further two
studies, and the terms of reference for the assignment were finally drawn in December, 1965.
We are conscious of the—if I can have the attention of the hon. Gentleman who took so much trouble in raising this debate, so that he can have a smear campaign against some of us on this side of the House, he might hear things that matter to his constituency. We are conscious of possible hindrance to the Dawley new town as a result of these studies, and therefore the terms of reference specifically required the consultants to advise the Department and the Dawley Development Corporation on what areas could be developed over the next four years without prejudice to the overall plan, so as to achieve continuity of development at a high level. The consultants did this quickly, and I am glad to say that the Development Corporation has already embarked on a continuity programme which is likely to keep it going for at least four years, during which time some 3,000 houses are programmed for completion.
Within this continuity programme is the redevelopment of the community of Madeley. The existing Madeley could hardly provide in its present state a district centre for the 26,000 people who will eventually live in and around it. In its redevelopment, which will be expensive, it will be necessary, unfortunately for some, to pull down or improve a number of obsolete properties. The proposal involves making a traffic-free centre of three linked squares, with shopping, housing, car parking and other communal facilities.
The Corporation hopes to buy much of the land in Madeley by agreement, but in dealing with cases where this, regrettably, may not be possible, it has submitted compulsory purchase orders for the area to be covered by the first phase of redevelopment. There have been objections, and if they are not withdrawn there will be an inquiry. In these circumstances, the hon. Member will understand if I make no further comment.
I now come to the difficult problem of getting industry into Dawley. Those new towns built to take overspill from conurbations must have industry. Everyone learnt when the first new towns were being built how important it
is to match houses and jobs, for otherwise the houses will remain empty or the inhabitants will travel far to work. No one on this side of the House, or, I imagine, anywhere in the House underestimates the difficulties of getting the right industry from the right places into the new towns and of phasing the movement of that industry to match the building of houses. But this is not to say that the Government can ignore the needs of the development districts. We must have a proper regard for priorities. But, having said that, let me assure the hon. Gentleman that it is our aim, in conjunction with the Board of Trade, to make the new towns a success.
Let it not be thought that no industry has yet been got for Dawley. There are a few firms already going there. At the moment, they amount only to a trickle, but I hope that firms in the Birmingham conurbation which have the right qualifications to go to Dawley will not just think that there is plenty of time but will go into action and try to get into Dawley as quickly as they can, because otherwise they will find that the trickle has turned into a torrent and they will not get the chance. I urge those firms which are interested to get in touch with the Development Corporation and the Board of Trade. The first generation of new towns were successful. The second generation towns will be even more successful and great places in which to live and work.
I want to say something about the slight delay there has been in producing the report on the first part of the consultants' study. This delay has been the subject of three recent Questions by my hon. Friend the Member for Wrekin, for whose intervention tonight I am much obliged. I know that in Dawley, Wellington and Oakengates, quite justifiably, people are anxious to know what is to happen in the future. I ask them to be patient for just a little longer, but I am able to announce tonight that the first part of the consultants' study, on which my hon. Friend has asked his Questions, will, it is understood, be available in September.
We are anxious to see that we get these reports right. To publish hastily might be to publish wrongly, which no one would want to happen. This is a diffi-
cult situation, with a number of areas involved in the new town development, and we want to make sure that, before we start on this enormous development, we are doing the right thing for the whole area.
I am much obliged to the hon. Gentleman for raising this matter tonight. Having been critical of me in his earlier remarks, he ended on a rather nice note, and I do not see why I should not do the same. I am grateful to him for drawing attention to the problems of the Dawley new town. I can assure him that I have already made arrangements to visit Dawley. I very much hope to manage it some time this month. I shall go down there myself and apologise personally to those I inconvenienced. But I remind the hon. Gentleman—I do not have to remind anyone else—that my first duty is to the House of Commons. It is inevitable that Ministers, in the course of their jobs, take on appointments in advance which the business of the House then demands that they alter. That I have expressed by apologies is quite clear to all.
I must add that the hon. Gentleman is in no position to make comments about the activity in making visits of my right hon. Friend the Minister or of myself as Parliamentary Secretary. In the last year and six months we have been in power, we have visited more new towns, more county councils and more conurbations than was ever done before in the history of the Ministry. That is a fact. My right hon. Friend, for example, has not had a weekend in London. He has spent them all in doing the job for which he was appointed as Minister. I can also claim, with modesty, to have visited 40 or 50 outside authorities, trying to do the same sort of job. If our record is being challenged on this, I would compare it with that of our predecessors and say that it is pretty good.

It is a pity that the Parliamentary Secretary did not go to the Midlands to learn a little of their problems, which London Members do not always understand. London Members are pretty clear about their own problems and usually very full of them, and it does no harm to visit the Midlands, particularly the part represented by my hon. Friend the Member
for Ludlow (Mr. More), to see what is going on there.
I wish to comment on the hon. Gentleman's reason for not going to the meeting to which he had been invited. We know that there was a three-line Whip out, but we know also that it is not unknown for Ministers to be allowed to ignore three-line Whips in order to do I heir jobs. How many of the hon. Gentleman's colleagues on the Treasury Bench were, in fact, doing Ministerial jobs yesterday? The names in the Division lists which followed later that evening show that they were not present.

There was then a two line Whip, after six o'clock. The hon. Gentleman can get up to all kinds of mischief, but let him not confuse the
issue about what happened yesterday in the first part of business. There was a three-line Whip for a Motion of censure on the Chairman, and after that Conservative Members were willing and able to pair. Until then, on the three-line Whip, as we know only too well, there was no pairing allowed by the Conservative Opposition, though that was not the attitude of the Labour Party.
The Question having been proposed after Ten o'clock and the debate having continued for half an hour, Mr. DEPUTY SPEAKER adjourned the House without Question put, pursuant to the Standing Order.
Adjourned at one minute to Eleven o'clock.
